commentBody:
There's a lot going on with this theme.  None of it bad or illogical, but I predict that quite a few inexperienced solvers will have difficulty with it, since it has two different conceits, depending on which direction the circles run.

And a lot of those commenters will blame the puzzle.

OMG, YES!
I’ll spare you the multilayered description of my multilayered aha’s.  Whatever Lewis says in the morning, times ten.

AES is one of my favorites, and now I add this:

AES, I ADMIRES ya!
An extra LEMON SCONE for you!
You get my SEAL OF APPROVAL!
CHEST BUMP, if that’s not too cringe.

I shall now go off and see what phrase might have a secret CANOE hiding within, such that when you ship it out, you’re left with another word. Yeah.

"I'm worried about this geometry test."
"You have nothing to sphere."

(Solid pun.)
One nit. In naval parlance, at least, a submarine (SUB) is referred to as a boat, not a ship.
Beef adobo isn't a thing. You make it with chicken or pork, never beef.
TIL a person with amnesia is an AMNESIC, not an amnesiac.

Caitlin suggests:
Today’s Theme
The only indications of today’s theme are eight sets of circled squares...

I suggest:
This is a Sunday when -- more than most -- reading the title is a very, very helpful indication of the theme.

I had little confidence in my solution but was pleased to get the music upon filling in the final square.  A few minutes under my average time.  I saw the title after I had filled the puzzle .  Cute theme.

In other news I screwed up the courage to enter a crossword contest at the local library.  3 NYT crosswords.  I think I did okay.

OMGYES I loved this. One of my favorite Sunday puzzles EVER. 

Boatloads of fun: fabulous clues (48A!, 78D), classic puzzle words (24A!, 59D!), delightful crossings (6D/18A!), blasts from the past (46A), not to mention (but I will) the brilliant construction.

Thanks, Alex! This made my day.

Sesh, not sess. Arrgghh. Spent way too much time looking for that error. This is the puzzle that clicks my streak odometer to 1100 so I was determined to find the hitch. Clever, clever puzzle. At first I expected theme answers to follow the same pattern. Re-reading the title helped trigger the aha moment about the orientation of the answer making all the difference. A lovely Sunday challenge.

Let me start by saying I like this puzzle, but it had me stymied for a while. Usually whenever a clue continues around the corner into the crossing word the crossing clue is a "dash mark." So it took me quite awhile to "suss" out the theme, but worth the wait.

I figured out how all the entries matched the clues, but when I finally realized the circles were all ships and shapes it raised the theme to LEGENDARY. 

Great work, Alex. A very fun and entertaining challenge.
Hardest puzzle of the week. Took me as long as the other six combined, just over an hour. The center west section was probably half of that, but I was a DIEHARD and powered through

Amusing puzzle, some tricky parts, a bit overburdened in the middle with all the idiolects of a diehard techie (CD drives, IBMs, IMO, OMG YES, Zapf, E-sign, even Reader & Slot fit right in) and maybe the strain of fitting in all the (very) clever themers can be seen in some of the awkward words toward the south: RC Car, Libelers, Steaded, Notelet (I've made a notelet to buy more aglets, BTW), Be Seen) but I also kinda love notelets, steaded and libelers, they come across as awkward only in that they're scarcely employed and don't come readily to tongue or pen, and scissors cuts, templates, amnesic, idiolects, ice holes, Dubliner, lemon scone all provide a rich substrate for this grid, mentally tickling me. 

But don't let me stop you from grousing about ORANG. Do you need some orang-aid to help with your sour dispositions, as if you ate your lemon scone too quickly? Because I can't help you. I have no egrets.

Loved this! My 16 year old daughter and I do the Sunday crossword together every week. She was the one who figured out the "Ship Out" part of the theme, I got the "Shape up". She is invaluable with OMGYES and song titles, I get the American clues since she moved to Aus when she was six. We both decided we didn't have enough testosterone to get the CHESTBUMP quickly.

Finished the puzzle, but with no help from the themers.  (I had no idea what that was all about.)  I'm sure it would have been more fun if I had SHAPEd UP instead of cHIPping OUT.  Stumbled on STEADED—a bit of head scratcher—but it worked so I'm not complaining, and fist BUMP made me frown until CHEST BUMP POPped up.

Alex Eaton-Salners, you are a man of many talents, as this construction confirms.  We needed a nice rich puzzle to console us in these troubled times.  Thank you.

Wow that was a slog.  I knew there was a clever hack I was missing at LEMONSC, but had to go to Wordplay to learn which one. 

Arcane, and yet, not.  I know we are going for polysemy, but can’t we stop at the 10th definition of something?

Random thoughts.
Oh, that Elizabeth, duh.
DIE HARD just happened to on TV as I was solving.
DAISY  and UVEA back again.
The crossing of SESH and STEADED was the last thing I got.
A trés JOLIE puzzle, Alex.
Merci

The puzzle's title was the big hint that made me aware of today's conceit. Picked up on the "shape" up with LEMONS[CONE], and the "ship" out with B[ARK]EEPER, so those got me going in the right "directions".

The puzzle had some challenges which took a little effort to get past, but overall this was one of my faster Sundays, and was definitely fun to worth through.

Thanks, Alex!
I never got the theme because I missed some of the circles. They can be very hard to see in dark mode. Maybe make circles white in dark mode?
Another ‘accidental’ finish - I was totally expecting to have to go back and fill in some rebus, but I was done.   Quite anticlimactic.   I guess I’ll read the column to find out what I missed.

As I normally do, I skipped the title before solving the puzzle. So while I quickly caught on to the trick in 26A BASKETBALL(STAR), I didn't realize that the ascending letters spelled a shape.

Skipping the title also meant being a little confused by answers such as 50A B(ARK)EEPER. I knew the answer was supposed to be BEEPER but didn't register that I was leaving out an ARK.

It wasn't particularly difficult to finish despite not fully grasping the theme. Once I took a look at the title, the significance of the circled letters made perfect sense.

Happy to say that I'm no longer one of 30+ million Americans (or at least not one of those Americans).
17 across uvea is part of the eye. uvula is the little grape  hanging from the back of the throat.

Kudos to all who solved this without looking at the theme hint !   I confess to always checking the puzzle title  on Sundays.   I still had to work out how to apply it, but I would've been quite stumped without that.

I found this puzzle a very enjoyable workout, with a good amount of wordplay solving.
It especially made me happy to correctly imagine  "idiolects" even though I don't believe I ever heard of it.  Something like a dialect for a single person?   The "Idio" prefix seemed a good guess, and a fun new word.

Can someone explain to me what is the meaning of BARGE SIN in relation to sloth? Or is it supposed to be BARGES IN? Stumped because I’ve always known it to be a group of DEADLY or CARDINAL. I’ve never heard of them being called BARGE SINS. 🤷🏻‍♂️
We, me and my daughter, got  the shapes but missed the boat on the concept of shipping out but it didn't matter because all the squares got filled in. I really liked the trivia and idiolects.
Luckily I knew all about that ole’ swinger Frank Sumatra, so that gave me a head start.

This was a disappointing puzzle for south east asians. As stated by a previous commentator, beef adobo isn't a thing. And I would like to add that ORANG also isn't a thing. I have voiced out this error on ORANG here before which was widely agreed in the comments section, so it's baffling how the editors just ignore this egregious error. Just clue it as "person in Bahasa" or "___ Utan"....is it so hard?

This was one of those puzzles that make me question my English skills in particular, and my education, life experience and intelligence in general. There was just so much I didn't know and failed to figure out! I feel like never attempting a NYT crossword again 🤣. It was so much more than just the trivia that defeated me today!

I sort of understood the theme on my own, but only grasped it fully having read the column. Perhaps the IQ test I once took that scored me at 70 was correct after all? (I was annoyed by some of the questions so I answered them randomly 🤪).

An example of my theme-related confusion, before understanding the theme: Paging device - BARKEEPER? I had no idea what the coach's name might be so bERR looked OK, and I thought maybe the disc device you get at some establishments to let you know your order is ready is called a BARbEEPER. (Now I know a BEEPER was indeed the correct answer, after losing the BAR...)

IDIOLECTS - that sounds more like an insult than anything else. "You're such an idiolect!" - I bet almost everybody would take that badly 🤣

Was of service to - STEADED? Could somebody explain that to me without questioning my intelligence? Because I've had enough of that today already 🤣
So glad Zapf Dingbats got some love today. For anyone who appreciates a good font joke (and who doesn’t?), Elle Cordova is brilliant: https://youtu.be/BXbW42uTKYo?si=0cO1ebSNghxwx3W9

On topic, briefly: I struggled today. Why and how? I wanted to tell you but...

I made the mistake of submitting an Andrzej-style post: long, detailed, explaining my difficulties and asking for help with understanding some things. But of course it did not make it past the automatic filter. My bad for thinking I could actually express myself on this board. I suppose I really have to refrain from making a mistake like that ever again.

It’s a comment section folks. All people are free to comment. Those who found it easy, those who found it obtuse, those who thought IDIOLECT is a neologism that only made it into the dictionary because the compilers lost the will to fight, and those who just came here to say:

Meh 🫤 it was okay. 

Made the train ride to Paris this morning less tiresome.
Not hard, but I only got the theme—ships and shapes—after I solved the puzzle, so not so much fun with this one.

Puzzles like this make me wonder if it’s better to read the title beforehand, or wait. Reading can sometimes spoil the fun of figuring out the theme, but waiting can mean being mystified throughout the solve. 

The latter was the case for me today. I caught on to the trick with the vertical circled letters early on, but I kept trying to append the horizontal letters to a Down entry and it just wasn’t happening. I had to read the column to finally get the theme, and that left me feeling underwhelmed.

Should I have peeked at the title? Probably. Will I do it next time? Probably not. I’m just stubborn that way.
I get that this one was supposed to be clever and all, but somehow that didn't make it very enjoyable.

Sorry to have this puzzle on a Sunday…except for it’s 25x25 size, isn’t this a Thursday puzzle? I suspect REBUS-style puzzles amuse their designers more than any solver. 

And on top of the first, second and third comments (recommended reading): some answers here are quite a stretch. 

I hope this puzzle was fun to build…but it wasn’t fun to solve.

The puzzle theme merited a 21-gun salute as it flew by well over my head. It was more like sink or swim over here for a while. A magnificent piece of showboating from the constructor and a real dreamboat of a puzzle. Next time I go up a certain creek, I’ll try to remember to bring a paddle.
Signed: First Admiral, Swiss Navy. Still at sea.

I avoid looking at the title to see if I can figure out the theme on my own.  After finishing, I had no idea why everything worked.  I knew I had to go up for some and leave out others, but that was about it.  After studying the grid, I noticed the ship types and saw that the circled words going up were shapes, but the theme idea never occurred to me.  Reading the title gave me a nice aha moment. Thanks for the extra treat, Alex.
Never, ever ask a British colleague if they are free for a sesh.

Now THIS is a Sunday puzzle!

I sussed  the “shape up”  rather quickly, but the “ship out” was a true aha moment.

Many thanks Mr. Eaton-Salners

(BTW- TEXANS: 30+ million/vegans: 9.6 million) That’ll learn me. . .
Pray tell, what is COMESAC?  I’ve looked at it 100 ways and still can’t “Finds” the logic.
I will make my usual plea to keep the gimmicky stuff to its allotted Thursdays.

I think I must be just about the only solver to have come across "idiolects" before, judging by the comments here.  It's a perfectly legitimate word. I particularly enjoyed the "steaded" and "libeler" type clues for their clever use of English. My thanks to the setter!

My favorite solving moment was, after wondering for a long time what layered topping an avocado toast might take on, getting EGG from a cross, then wondering for a split second more what the heck kind of layers an egg has, then, with a huge “Hah!” getting HEN.  Not just a bam, but a bam-BAM!  Oh, I’ve seen the hen/layer trick before, but I fell for it again, and I simply adore getting got good like that.

There was plenty more for me to like as well.  Plenty of cluing pushback, with areas that required several returns, giving my brain the rub it savors.  Lovely NYT puzzle debuts OLD AS TIME and SEAL OF APPROVAL.

Plus the theme itself, how that lively title phrase was literally played out in the box – a terrific idea, IMO. After I caught on to it, it helped my solve. And nerdy me liked seeing five palindromes and the contrasting PuzzPair© of ABED and a backward PUMA.

I love the backstory, with Alex working on this puzzle for more than five years, rejecting versions for being too dull.  This is an artist as well as a craftsman, one who keeps the solver and excellence to the fore.

Altogether, Alex, this was one terrific Sunday, a most splendid outing.  Thank you, sir!

That genuinely hurt my brain. HEH! It took me 45 mins longer than yesterday's. HISS! 

One ADMIRES those who sped through this. I only looked at the theme cos it kept flashing at me and I still managed to miss the 'ship out' aspect. Oopsie DAISY. Only got it two mins before I finished and just before I realised there aren't 30  million TeMans in America. AHAS all around.

I don't misuse words; I employ idiolects.

Was I the only one who was dissatisfied with today's puzzle? It seemed that the gimmick existed merely to justify a snappy title, and not the other way around. Some of the theme entries, like LEMONS(CONE), were end-checked; others, like COMES(CROSS), were not. And the "star" of BASKETBALL(STAR), means, well, "star." (RATS/STAR does give @ Lewis--whose post I haven't read yet--a good reason to pull out his "semordnilap.") And "tract" and (SUB)TRACT have a clumsy etymological connection, as does, I suppose, "cross" and "across."

Not being familiar with the acronym RINO, I guessed "dINO," as in "dinosaur."  Abe is rolling in his grave.

Multa obstat.

(Maybe I'm just in a snit because I couldn't find a good YouTube clip of the driving instructor teaching Lisa how to use her pernundel. IYKYK.)

A case where, for me, the theme steaded the constructor or the admirerers of puzzle architecture more than the funness of the solving experience.

Off to check the official dimensional ranges of note cards versus  notelets (humongous eye roll).

As a reminder to online solvers who say they "cheat" on Sundays and look at the puzzle title (or debate whether to "cheat" and look), the title has never been optional for those who solve the crossword in the Sunday Magazine. The editor's note, added a few years ago, is also not an option. https://www.nytimes.com/svc/crosswords/v2/puzzle/print/Nov2424.pdf

I always thought runners were a rare and generous group.  Post race, people would stand around and talk about their times, and there could be a sub 3 hour marathoner congratulating a 4+ hour marathoner on their time, knowing it was a good time for that person.  More experienced runners would give tips on pacing and strategy.  No one seemed insulted or jealous if you mentioned your time.  Maybe, just like here, there were people lurking in the shadows with their nose out of joint, taking snipes at the "braggarts", but I was just having too much fun to notice.

Whew. I almost bother to remember the puzzle title and I didn't today, so I only half-tumbled to the trick(s) even once I started to figure out some of the theme answers. Still a tough work-out even after that, and I cheated a bit but I guess I'll allow that today. 

This was a pretty amazing feat of construction. Just can't imagine what it would take to put something like this together. 

Really different puzzle find today. A Monday from January 23, 2006 by Mark T. Milhet. The theme clues and answers: 

"OVALS :" 
TWENTYSEVENDOWN

"K :"
TOPRIGHTCORNER

"STORY :"
LASTWORDACROSS

"X :"
CENTEROFTHEGRID

Can't imagine how it would have been possible to figure that one out. 

I'm done. 

..

I thought BARbEEPER was perfectly cromulent since that's the system at our local to pick up your food.  Sorry Coach. 

The most fun were the "What the . . .?" moments followed by "Oh, riiiiiiiight" which included connecting the title to the theme afterward (much afterward).  

Good fun, glad I stuck with it.  Thanks.

Fun puzzle today.

Working on my own I got the up part of Shape Up, but until I read the column I didn't quite see that the up words were all shapes. Going up was enough to solve all four of them.

I got the across answers that included the ships, mostly, but really got stuck with Coach Steve. I know I've seen many quotes from Steve KERR, and I've always been happy to see a prominent sports figure take unapologetically liberal positions (you don't usually see that from football coaches, say), but I had a hard time coming up with his last name. Is there also a Steve KEmp? When that was what I had filled in I was stuck for a while and I was briefly wondering if I needed to erase a whole lot and finish 67A with DEADLY.

Thanks!
Took a minute (or two, or three) to catch on, but what a great time getting there. Good way to start the day—fair winds and following seas, all.

My goodness, that was a Sunday with bells on. I wasn’t finding the clues too tricky to start with and cottoned onto the SHAPE section of the title quickly. Just as I got comfortable the constructor (literally) turned it on its head and I didn’t know what was going on. COMESAC and LEMONSC had me scratching my head for so long. Caitlin’s column as always shed a little light, but it was still a tough grid to complete. I loved the theme within a theme, just to keep us on our toes. Well done.

Storm Bert is beginning to ease up now. The wind has dropped but the rain still pours. We’ve lost two huge pines to the snow/wind combination but no loss of fences or hedges. We can spend the next month hauling and chopping for next year’s firewood. Our track is under water but why go out, when I can sit in front of a fire, cuppa in one hand and crossword in the other. Lovely.
2 hours and 2 seconds and sleeping on it to solve this one without lookups. BARKEEPER nearly did me in!

I enjoyed the solve.
Very much.

The theme was *not* the highlight for me, 
but more a bunch of hoops and loop-de-loops
I had to jump through to get 
the music.

Good thing I don’t mind jumping through hoops!
I quite enjoy it, actually.

Felt a wee bit like the archives to me.

Thanks for the challenge!

Happy Sunday all!

excellent sunday puzzle today! not too easy but not impossible; the title really helped to figure out the theme, which I found to be straightforward and logical (always appreciated). fave clues are 60A, 121A, 78D!
If I am solving this on an iPad, how can I see the puzzle’s title? I could not possibly have known the theme until reading the info blog after finishing
Not my favorite.
I wish the iPad version would allow me to see the title! Knowing “Shape Up or Ship Out” would have made the solve smoother and more fun

Off to FTMEADE to use an Enigma Machine to figure out what NOTELET is code for.

Thank you Alex a fun solve except for NOTELET. Have I mentioned NOTELET yet?
I was not impressed with the theme.  It seems like he had two ok ideas that when joined resulted in a confusing, disjointed puzzle

Alex....Alex, Alex, Alex.
You have really outdone yourself!  
This was LEGENDARY!  I mean it.  Unforgettable!  
As in:  I won't get that HOUR back.  (I didn't actually look at the clock, but  it felt at least that long.)
Yessirree, just me and my magnifying glass and my trusty pen, slaving away here at the dinner table with tears in my eyes....from the strain, that is.
OLD AS TIME?  Yeah, I expect I've aged twice as much due to the stress.  Not that it wasn't fun....putting answers in, then taking them out, then putting them back.
RSVP or BYOB?  OOPS or OH HI?

Would this puzzle count as a  DEADL(rats)Y SIN?

Juuuust kidding.  
Once I looked at the title of the puzzle, it was much funner.
It was mostly a great puzzle....But the NBA coach was really unfair.
Ok, how many were singing the song from Phineas & Ferb for 24A?
Impressive construction, but for me,  hard on the eyes.  I’m sure I’m not the only one, but haven’t read the comments yet.
Any viewers of the Simpsons know that a BARKEEPER is a paging device, as evidenced by Bart’s many prank calls.  “I’m looking for Amanda. Last name Huginkiss.”
Yes!!! More like this! One of my favorites ever. Thank you!!
A puzzle within a puzzle. This was so much fun! Thanks
Quite fun!

Don’t know why the reviewer isn’t familiar with Sloth being one of the seven deadly sins. 

The non-themed clues were often very obscure. Either better clue writing or less eccentricity would have helped.

Hats off to another rare theme that is useful and interesting for me as a solver. I didn't catch on completely -- I found the theme answers that went up, but didn't have enough correct fill to catch on to the ones that didn't -- until I read the title. A very enjoyable puzzle. Thanks, Alex Eaton-Salners!

What a rush of adrenaline constructing this puzzle must have provided!  What an accomplishment!  All those circles going up produce shapes and all those circles going across produce ships!  Wow!

I missed more than half of the whole shebang while solving.

Oh, I did see the circles going up that were needed to complete the clue: LEMON SCONE and BASKETBALL STAR and such.  I needed them to solve, you see.  It took me until I was almost finished solving to realize that the circles going sideways needed to be removed.  "Offed", if you will.  My very first fill-in, realizing that, was SIN for "sloth", ignoring BARGE.  Two different parts of the puzzle doing two different things and I was slow to catch on.

But in neither case did I notice either the SHAPES or the SHIPS.  I patted myself on the back for filling in SEAL OF APPROVAL -- missing the OVAL entirely.  Which was the story of my entire solve.

So a construction coup mostly not shared by me, the solver.  Which is always, always the problem with this kind of puzzle.  But I do understand that those of you who are more visually perceptive than I am  -- a very, very low bar, I might add -- may have had an entirely different and more exciting experience.  At any rate, I applaud the effort that went into creating this.
Pure tedium
"...including the Puns and Anagrams found in this issue." Way to poke at a sore spot for us online subscribers! We haven't forgotten that, once upon a time, we could enjoy variety puzzles online.
Too clever by half. The crossword equivalent of a puffy shirt - it calls attention to the constructor but is otherwise tiresome.
Shouldn't "Four Corners tribe" be Ute instead of Utes?
Complex and fun like any given Sunday - I just had AHAS when I came across COMESAC with SCISSORCUTS which helped me realize that RCCAR was not Drone nor Robot. Phew. Back to work. Thank you!!

If I have to read the blog to figure out the puzzle its not agood puzzle for me. 

Struggled with this. took too long to get it all

A puzzle probably more fun to think up than it was to solve. 

On to Monday

I often fill in the NYT crossword puzzles on my mini phone, as I did today. So either I work a quadrant, to make it easier to read, or the whole puzzle and struggle with the tiny type, but either way I tend to miss things, such as today. I did not completely understand the theme of this one until I looked at it on my computer. Such an impressive puzzle!

I was able to solve this fairly quickly. I found the cross-fill to be thoughtful. Every single entry was perfectly plausible, even without a complete understanding of what was going on. Kudos to the author!

What?! Uveas taste nothing like grapes! (Cornea at least makes a kernel of sense)

Great double theme.

Why can't I remember if I've seen Memento?

I solved it. Got the shape up part of the theme, but not the ship out part.
Even after I finished.
nice puzzle. impossible to figure out without the column but I read the column, I'm not proud. I don't want to spend tedious hours trying to decipher the undecipherable.

I never see or "get" themes.  They are almost always above my head.  I just plug away and try to solve the puzzle, which I did with today's pleasant version.  If I have time, I love to read Gameplay, so I can be informed of the clever theme that flew over my ducked noggin!  This was fun.  One of my wrong guesses made me laugh--OLDASDIRT instead of TIME, and I had others that just gummed me up, but I deleted and got on with it.
Since I'm an online solver, I can go back and dredge up 20 years of archived puzzles, and I love to do the Sundays at a snail's pace, savoring the themes and trying to see them.  Most of the time, I fail, but it's great fun either way.  (What's extra-funny is those 19-year-old references to current people or events that I have to dredge up from my memory bank--or just give up and look up--which have since been consigned to oblivion.)

I always forget to read the puzzle title. Usually it doesn’t matter. Today, well, I solved it with a ¯\_(ツ)_/¯. Cute idea but would’ve been more fun if I’d only read the title first. What if the title actually came up when you loaded the puzzle, instead of having to go to the info page?
Fun, took me almost an hour but that's what I like about Sundays. Thanks for a great puzzle.

For me, this was a perfect Sunday puzzle. I never got bogged down and was always able to find something I could solve to keep making progress overall. Had a “duh” moment when I finally filled in FTMEADE…since I was stationed there many decades ago. It did strike me that there were a number of answers that appeared in some way or another in recent puzzles: REFS, UVEA, BRAVA, DAISY. Am I right about that? Enjoyable puzzle with a clever theme. Nice Sunday diversion.

I've baked and bought thousands of scones but never had a lemon scone! Plain, cheese or fruit only.

Too many unknown facts for me today, but I got an enormous amount of clues by the crossers, even JOBSACT although I had no idea about the theme. I looked up unknowns like RINO and NECCO but I knew IDIOLECT somehow. 
And I thought JA must be a basketball/football player's name - and I know German!
Fun fact: botanically, a notelet is not a true note. Due to its size and tendency to get lost, it is scientifically classified as a scrap of paper.

Interesting reading the discussion. I'm clearly not like the average solver -- I found yesterday pretty tough and today on the easy side. I got enough of the theme to bumble my way through but had to come here after I solved the puzzle to really "get it." That didn't bother me though -- overall it was a fun puzzle, and the streak lives on!

I like puzzles like this so I’ll chime in for the defense. I cottoned on to taking the ship out fairly quickly at SUBTRACT but I was woefully late adding the shape up to its connecting answer. 
If I have a quibble it’s STEADED being OLD AS TIME.

I couldn’t figure out the theme — only that some words went up? But I solved it anyway, and now feel dumb for not considering the puzzle title. 

Very clever!

Satisfying aha experience for me when I finally got "ship out." I spent way too much time trying to figure out how the horizontal circled letters fit with a down answer - I was so sure I'd figured out how the puzzle worked after getting LEMON SCONE and BASKETBALL STAR. I must have read the title a dozen times before I grokked it. 

I was cursing the constructor for a while because of those boats. I needed the crosses to get the downs that connected to them (especially Steve KERR), and before that aha moment all I knew was that the across answer didn't make sense with the clue. 

Good puzzle! I found yesterday's pretty easy, but definitely got my comeuppance today.

I've never had avocado toast, unless you count guacamole, which (for me) is just a delivery medium for Tabasco sauce. Why would you put an EGG on it? Scrambled or fried? Please don't tell me it's hard boiled. Seriously, I'm making myself nauseous over here.
Way too complicated!! Not worth the time.

Why isn't "OMG yes" OMGY ?

#tongueincheek
#imold
Interesting. I just had four posts eaten. Tested it, and it turns out the offending word was the word that refers to repairing socks. No matter how it is used in a sentence.

I wholly agree with Rex Parker’s opinion of this puzzle. Always check out his blog to cheat on the areas I find maddening like that Land of Nod section where RINO OHHI and AHAS show up. Read his post on this puzzle for legitimate criticism of lazy clueing and a lack of understanding of terminology used. I saw the title of this puzzle and thought: Not another Battleship game rip-off. It was close. And I can’t let this one go by…. COMESAC? Inane frat boy humor leaking into the puzzles now? What’s next? Penis shaped grids?
I hate to say this but I was bored by the whole thing.  The theme was too much of a stretch for me.  Sorry.  😕
I liked the "Shape Up" aspect of the puzzle; not so impressed by the "Ship Out" with the exception of B[ARK]EEPER, I think because there the ship was embedded.

I thought this was a very challenging and clever puzzle. I missed the gold star by one letter, but I am glad I ran check puzzle, since the names of coaches are a mystery to me and I never would have gotten that.

@T I've said this before when it's come up, and I'll say it again, and you probably won't like it anyway, but here goes: Yes, ORANG means person in the Indonesian language. Many of us know that. But this is an English puzzle, and unless the puzzle is going for a foreign language clue like "...in Sumatra", the answer is in English. When loan words come into a new language, there is often a semantic shift. Latte means milk in Italian, but in English, it's a coffee drink with milk in it. An entree is an appetizer in French, but in American English, it's a main dish. These were originally mistaken usages, but they're firmly planted in the English language today. Using them the English way is not a mistake. Simply stated, ORANG in English is just a shortening of orangutan. Just like hippo, rhino, dino, etc. No one is insulting Indonesians by calling people apes. I guarantee fewer than 1% of English speakers know that ORANG means person in Bahasa. In fact, fewer than 1% know what language they speak in Indonesia at all. If you wish to take offense on behalf of the Indonesian people, feel free to. I promise you, no one is calling Indonesian people apes. https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/orang
